segments.text: This is May 16, and we are in the Hagler Center, and I have the pleasure and honor of chatting with Eddie Joe Davis, who is the exact title now?
President of the Texas A&M Development Foundation.
Texas A&M Foundation.
Texas A&M Foundation.
Okay, now we're going to cut this off and see if it works.

Because someone in the future may listen to this or read it and not know your background, let's begin with your talking about where you grew up, family, what was the family income, where was it, and so forth.
That was probably typical of most students coming to Texas A&M in the early 60s.
And I grew up on a little farming ranch, 160 acres, inherited from my grandfather, who homesteaded with the objective of obtaining a quarter section for each child.
And so my dad was the only one of about six or seven children who decided to stay and farm it.
And he farmed all the rest of the quarter sections of the children who went to California and other places.
This is where?
Clay County.

Went to high school or to all school in Henrietta, although it was a little place called the Stanfield Ranch, which was put together by Stanfield brothers and then broken up into parcels and sold in the late 1800s.

they would have gone to school at Stanfield except they closed the one through eight grade school the year before I started school and then wrote a yellow dog school bus well what was between probably 23 and 25 miles a day to Henrietta to school
Raised cotton, wheat, maize or milo were few cattle.
Most of everything we had we produced our own food, milk, meat.
still was in an environment sort of at the last of the end of an era, I guess, in that we would move around the little community and have hog killing in the fall, go from one house to the next.
And we also, I guess we first got running water when I was about, oh, about first grade, something like that.
The one-holer was near the chicken house, so it wouldn't smell, you understand.
That is, the chicken took, you know, dominated.
It was a pretty Spartan, sparse upbringing.
They had two older brothers, both much older, 11 and 17 years older, so they were more like uncles and brothers.
My theory was that my dad always wanted to have a hoe hand at home, so he spread them out, and that was the place that we began.
You've told me in other conversations, I believe, about your father kind of assigning you a few acres that if you wanted to go to college, you work that and that income.
Describe that arrangement.
He and I basically farmed 160 plus, probably another 500 cultivated, and we ran cows on about another 300 acres.
So we sharecropped and leased, and it kept us pretty busy.
But the summer, I guess it was really the spring before my first year in college, and frankly, I didn't yet know where I was going to go at that point.
It was a little different in those days.
He pointed out to me a terrace and a fence row that if you took the circumference around that, it was about 13 acres.
And he said, you, like you always do, help farm the whole thing.
But whatever we make on that 13 acres of cotton is what you'll have to go to school on.
Well, we made $100 an acre.
So I had $1,300 to get me through my first year at A&M.
And it was right on target.
It was just about what it took.
Plus, the other part of the story is we were sitting on the front porch shelling black-eyed peas

probably around the 4th of July and my dad had gone to the mailbox it rained the night before so we couldn't work normal work so we were shelling peas he walks to the mailbox heads back up and I noticed a little extra spring in his step when he gets back to the front porch hands me an envelope in which I am told that I've received an opportunity award scholarship and that was the decision point

frankly for i mean i had wanted to go to a m but didn't know that i could afford it where had you heard about a m and what primarily a couple of sources one my ag teacher was a a m graduate he was a non-traditional aggie in that he
came to A&M after World War II as a veteran and had finished school.
And so he wasn't, you know, he wasn't a part of the Corps.
In fact, he really didn't know a lot about the Corps.
Also a fellow named Penrose B. Metcalf, who you might have heard of.
Penrose Metcalf was a great friend of people in the Future Farmers of America.
I was a district, you know, local district
regional and then state FFA officer in the FFA and Mr. Metcalf would haul us boys around
try to teach us a little bit about what it was like to be in the grown-up world.
And he talked fondly about us going to college, which we hadn't all thought about very much.
And A&M was always on his mind.
And then I had a fellow that was a class ahead of me in Henrietta that came here.
Again, sort of similar background that I knew, not real well, named Eddie Shear.
And Eddie was a contact for me down here.
So those are the things.
Now my dad always admired A&M because of the extension service.
You know, they helped him with his bull worm problems and all of the other things that you endure and of course all of the ag community were familiar with A&M.
So it was a natural link.
Had you been to visit the campus?
I came my senior year in high school and spent the night with some kids in the Corps.
It wasn't an organized event in those days.
Frankly, that was probably not a great motivator.

I mean, it was okay, but the night I was here, it was dreary and rainy and dark and dank, and I wasn't sure that this was the kind of place for me, but I was, again, remained convinced that it was a good school and everybody thought highly of it.
As far as you know, when did you apply?
When did you start filling out some papers?
It was probably late spring, my senior year in high school.

i remember a friend of mine and i staying up and studying for quote the sat or act or whatever it was in those days you didn't have to have it to get in excuse me there wasn't a required score you had to take the test so i guess they were trying to see you know kind of where you were and then the the final decision was that that endowed or not endowed but the opportunity award how much was it 125
I think it was $250 a year, you got $125 a semester.
And then I had a valedictory scholarship, which allowed the tuition to be waived and my lab fees to be paid.
So with all that combined, it was pretty substantial relative to the cost.
So you were first in a class of how many?
11 boys and 22 girls, I might add.
Pretty good ratio.
All right, as a sidelight, why that 2 to 1 male-female?
I have no idea.
Was there just a bigger dropout rate of the boys?
Probably.
You know, when you think about it, I mean, I had a first cousin who was very close to me who dropped out after his sophomore year, and it was pretty common in those days.

uh... college was uh... sort of on the horizon not very many people thought about it did you have any idea before you got here what your major might be no uh... in fact uh... my mother and dad brought me down to after this arrival of the scholarship
There was some information in there about you ought to come down before classes begin to meet with, you know, the college.
And I did, I was thinking probably agriculture, but I didn't know what.
And so we arranged to pass through College Station on the way to Galvin.
a couple of days at Galveston, meeting some relatives, and stop off here and met with Dr. R.C.
Potts, Dick Potts.
And he was over in the old heap building, the one on, now I guess, I don't know what it's called, but it was the dairy science, and always smelled like lab chemicals.
Anyway, Dr. Potts' office was up on the third floor and we were sitting there and he looked at my high school transcript and said, well, Eddie Joe, you need to be an ag journalism major.
And I said, well, Dr. Potts, what's that?
And he said, well, you've got, obviously you like English and you can write.
You've got good grades in high school English.
You know, you've got this background in agriculture.
It's a great program.
A lot of future in this.
People can, you know, you can do a lot of different things.
He was a real promoter of agricultural journalism.
So I said, hey, sounds good to me.
And that's how I started and that's how I finished.
Now, there was one other major influence
And that is that Anderson Clayton gave a $1,000 scholarship in the junior and senior year to someone in ag journalism.
Well, I had my eyes on that, and I needed the money.
So I thought, well, if I can do well enough in the freshman and sophomore year, I might be able to latch on to that scholarship.
And that was the motivator.
And so you came briefly early in the summer?
Sometime, probably, I would say July.

uh was there other than meeting dr potts did you carry any impression of the campus away there was a there was a general meeting in the uh i think it was on the second floor of the chemistry building in a you know lord not the old large general lecture hall but in large probably a hundred student lecture hall
And it was sort of an orientation.
At the end of it, by the way, you picked your core outfit, quote.
Actually, it was picked for you because what they did in those days is they assigned you by major.
And as an ag major, I had the choice of if I wanted to be in the Air Force, I could be in Squadron 6.
If I wanted to be in the Army, I could be in C1 or D1.
Well, I didn't know what one or the other meant.
So I get in line.
They split you off.
And they ask you, you want to be Army or Air Force?
You tell them, and they put you in the outfit.
those were interesting places because of the mix of the people, mostly old country boys.
And it was a different experience.
I mean, the people weren't different, but putting them together in that kind of an arrangement was different.
But that's the only other memory I have about the place.
There was no advanced placement test.
There was no
hooping and hollering and all the good stuff that they do these days, it was pretty get them in, get them out, we got better things to do.
Alright, so then you go home and then come back.
Oh, and I did sign up for fish camp.
Oh, okay.
Yeah, and that was one of the other things you did while you were here.
Again, not quite knowing what that was.

but being encouraged by gordon gay i think was the person that as i recall was the person that really motivated everybody to sign up for fish camp who was you know the old uh director of the y director of the ymca and the campus minister uh describe fish camp as as you uh understood it
Well, it was really not a bad experience.
I met a lot of people at fish camp, just like happens today, that sort of remain your relationships throughout your college experience.
A friend of mine named Barney Fudge from Burke Burnett, Texas, and I were in the same cabin at fish camp.
And neither one of us knew we were
although we had played sports against each other in high school, we didn't know we were both coming here.
So Barney and I formed a fast.
And there's an interesting end to that story, which we can save until later, with regard to the senior year.
And Fish Camp was then held?
Palestine.
At the Methodist?
Right, Methodist Assembly.
And did you, was it a worthy event?
At worthwhile investment of time?
When you're 18 years old, it's pretty hard to judge.
No, but as you look.
What was or wasn't.
Oh, yeah, I thought it was, again, it wasn't nearly as organized nor as tradition-bound.
What it really was in those days was a way to help you think about transitioning away from home

uh there was a lot of spiritual based uh discussion again gordon gay was was a principal in it and it was probably more being thoughtful about uh not losing all of your values and and leaving home and forgetting home and and then of course a lot of things about a m but not in the sense that you're taught today that i at least from my observation about
the rah-rah tradition oriented.
It was much more of a quiet, a little simpler activity.
All right, so you go back home and then come back.
No, didn't go back home.
Came here, went to fish camp, and then came back from fish camp.
How did you get here for that fish camp trip?
Well, I was a rare person.
My dad had bought the first new automobile we ever owned in 1957.
We had a pretty nice wheat crop.
He bought a 57 Ford.

the cheapest model ever made okay i mean it was it had no chrome it had no in fact we had it suited out with those clear plastic seats as soon as we got it out of the dealership it cost 1900 never never forget it in the fall in the fall of 1963 my dad bought a pickup truck because he was tired of hauling things around in that 57 ford and
Told me I could bring it to A&M.
So I was one of the rare characters.
In my outfit of freshman, there were three cars, about probably 30, 35 kids.
So I drove down here.
As far as you can recall, what did you bring?
What possessions did you bring?
I had a footlocker.
and I think everything I owned was in that footlocker.
Did you bring many civilian clothes at all?
I didn't have any civilian, I mean I had I had five pair of Levi's and I had five because that way my mother only had to wash once a week and mostly
For graduation, I got white shirts, short-sleeved, from John's Dry Goods in Henrietta, Texas.
So I had a few white short-sleeved shirts, two pair of cowboy boots.
It went a long time in my life not knowing that you could cut boots off and make shoes out of them.
And those Levi's, and that was about it.
Did you bring a radio or a record player?
I had a little sort of table record player, which my dad had bought at Second Monday in Bowie some years before.
Didn't have many records, but brought what I had.
My sophomore roommate, by the way, had a brother who had a great jazz collection, and so I became a jazz fan during my sophomore year.
But that was sort of what you did.
You accumulated around what everybody brought, but not many possessions.
I think...
I believe I had an oscillating fan too, which became fairly important in those old norms that didn't have any air conditioning.
When did you get assigned to a room?
Was it before fish camp or after?
I think I came and put my stuff in the room when I arrived, and then left maybe that same day.
Describe for an observer how one got broken into the Corps in those days.
Well, I had a little bit of an awakening because I wasn't, although I knew, one of the things I remember, and I think I still have it somewhere, was I got a fish handbook.
that was produced by the YMCA.

and that came to me sometime between the agreement to come and showing up and it had stuff in there like what do you call the food and how do you you know what what's whip out mean all that stuff so you're sort of figuring this out a little bit but not very much because as you make your way into the dorm you know you're looking for help you got a foot locker that weighs 60 pounds or something you're trying to get to the fourth floor
And all of a sudden, people start yelling at you for no good reason.
You know, you just showed up.
And they begin to give you instructions in a rather forceful manner.
My freshman company commander was a guy named Charlie Fisher from Cuero.
And Charlie was a guy who was, he was probably the, of the models you could have, he was more the gentle type.
And that whole senior class was a good senior class, smart people I remember, many of them.
That'd be class of 64?
That'd be the class of 64.
The classes sort of got worse as you went down in time.
And I'm counting my own in that group.
The juniors were probably not as good a quality.
The sophomores were worse.
And we were just a bunch of ragtags.
And the first sergeant was a guy named Robert Parker, and he was really quite the opposite of Charlie Fisher.
So, you know, what I remember about it is, and also I remember meeting my fish old lady, a fellow named Fred Youngman from Rio Medina over near San Antonio.
First time I'd really ever been around a good Catholic boy.
In fact, one of my first memories in the room was the first night we spent together in the room.
It had been a rather hectic day.
I was in the top bunk, had just gone to bed.
Fred had stayed up to study, had his desk lamp on.

and i was in that little period when you're half asleep but not quite i woke startled and noticed he was on his knees next to the bed and i thought he was sick and i started saying fred fred are you okay fred are you okay and he looked up and he said i'm praying
I think for survival, but it just had never occurred to me to get on your knees as he had done and pray.
So that was an early introduction to diversity, let's put it that way.
And this was Company C?
What was the nickname?
Saber C. Saber C. Or C-Troop Jocks.
It was an old cavalry outfit, in fact, where
other than the Ross Volunteers, we're the only outfit to wear yellow.
We wore yellow, whatever you call those things, mascots.
And what else was distinctive about it as C Troop thought about itself?
Oh, again, it was...
The person who came, one of the things I noticed about A&M early on was everybody was from Houston.
You know, you show up from a little town of Henrietta, everybody you meet on the campus, it seemed like, was from Houston, which was like a foreign land to me.
But in our little outfit, most of those boys were from places like Merkle and Aspermont and Fate and, you know, Schulenburg and Weimar.
And to have someone from Houston was a rarity because, again, we were an ag outfit, and what they did is they stashed all of the old ag boys in there.
As a result, collectively, there was not a lot of brain power in the outfit.
It was just a collection of good old boys.
And as a result, our activities and our fun tended to revolve around things that country boys would do.
My junior roommate was a fellow from Dallas.
And he was, by today's standards, or those days standards, a sophisticate.
And then we had a couple of guys come in as frogs

from houston who i guess they didn't have any other place to put them they put them in our outfit and they were both sort of city boys with money which we didn't and it turned out to be if they survived that transition they were really good guys and these were and this is mid-september
Yeah, we started actually I guess about September the 15th or so.
In those days, you started later.
And one of the memories, by the way, of the first week was there must have been a tropical depression or hurricane in the Gulf.
And I came from where it hadn't rained since, you know, usually there was one rain midsummer.

it started raining the day we got here and it rained for about ten straight days I thought I had never seen so much water in all my life and we before you know the other memory of the first week or so as soon as you got here
they hauled you over by marching you to the old property warehouse, military property warehouse, which was in the shadow of the water tower.

And you would get in line, and you'd walk down the line, and there were these old guys probably from the Brazos bottom that had been doing this for 1,000 years, and they'd look at you and go, and they'd throw you some khakis.
I mean, and all they were trying to do was sort of get it within maybe six or eight inches of correct.
You get back to the dorm, put these things on, and they were hanging all over you.
So there were places all around the campus, park cleaners are still over here, that you had to then find your way to those places to get those uniforms fitted
Because you couldn't, I mean, there wasn't any, you didn't go down and think about it and try it on and all that stuff.
They just threw it to you.
You stuffed it in a duffel bag and hoped that you could get it close.
Well, that was traumatic because you were in little dressing rooms with these curtains that pulled back and forth.
It was September in Bryan College Station.
No place was air conditioned.
Mm-hmm.
By the time you got the khakis on, they were wilted.
So it was really, that part I do not remember fondly, believe me.
Describe how the sophomores and the other members of the Corps got you guys straightened out and acclimated to the...
There was probably...
Oh, and I know you know the routine, typically up at 6 with on the wall, which we called on the wall by 620.
And at that point in time, you went through inspections.
If you weren't the whistle jockey, if you were the whistle jockey, you started a lot earlier.
because you were responsible for running three cycles of waking everybody up.
People must have been very hard to wake up because that was loud and rather disruptive to your own schedule.
But during the time you were on the wall, you were intensely scrutinized with regard to your appearance, your uniform, your brass,

you know another thing was they gave you brass that had the you know what we call maidenhead it had sprayed on lacquer and the first thing you had to do was get that damn lacquer off of it you know you couldn't be seen with so this was traumatic because none of us knew how to do that and so part of the

training was to show you how to turn the water on in the sink, run it till it got so hot that it would melt the sink, and then put this brass tin in there and run it until you finally had melted that maidenhead off.
And then you had to shine it.
And then you'd have little bits in the cracks, and they would jump all over you for that.
Then you typically made it downstairs to formation and off to morning chow.
And you never stopped being inspected or harassed.
That was the official part.

And then there was, you know, I think we might have been here a few days before class started because we spent a lot of time marching and learning how to march and all the proper military courtesy and all that.
Had you had any, you had not been in any kind of military in high school or anything like that?
Not in Henrietta.
Yeah, this is all brand new.
All brand new.
The only thing was my brother was in the Navy and he brought me home a Blue Jackets manual.

from and I had worn that thing out going through it learning about you know how to fold clothes and all that stuff didn't have any any real relationship to this but no there was no military training in high school the unfortunately in those days
Except for call to quarters, which was right after chow till 10.30.
You know, you were fair game for a sophomore or anybody else anytime you were in the dorm and anytime after call to quarters.
I mean, they did tend to protect that three-hour period in there for study.
But any other time, you found little nooks and crannies around the campus to hide.
Such as?
What were those nooks and crannies?
Oh, the library was a favorite.
And it sort of bothered them a little bit because there they could see you and knew you were there and knew they couldn't get their hands on you.
The MSC was also sort of protected turf.
Spent a lot of time under the wings of the Medal of Honor winners along that north portico of the MSC.
And, you know, occasionally you would find a classroom or a building where there was a little place you could hide out, but those were the two main things, two main places.
How did you, those courses, your first fall, how did you select the courses you were taking?
I didn't.
I had no, there was no selection.
I was assigned
I took 17 hours my freshman's fall semester, which was considered a light load.
And I was the only freshman in our outfit that was my distinguished student the fall semester.
Why that's important was
It was sort of hard for everybody to figure out because they didn't see me studying any more than anybody else did.
And I probably didn't.
But what happened was a little high school where I went, I had an old made English teacher who was quite good.
Didn't know it then.
I understand it now.
Had a chemistry teacher who was a person right out of college.
He went to North Texas, ran track, and was the track coach, but taught chemistry.
but was an extraordinary teacher.
A math teacher named Mr. Beeler, B-E-E-L-E-R, who had a speech impediment, so all of his words were hard to understand, but the guy was a good math teacher.
So I came to A&M basically with an ability to pass that first semester no problem.
Second semester, I hit second semester chemistry, sort of went the other direction.
Another interesting part of that is I had...
I was color blind.
And so one of the things you had to do in the chemistry lab was to titrate.
And I couldn't tell whenever it turned colors.
I just poured until the chemicals ran out.
And then someone else would have to show me.
